revision.text:
'''Aliens Appeals Board''' ({{lang-sv|Utlänningsnämnden}}, UN) was a [[Government agencies in Sweden|Swedish government agency]] that answered to the [[Ministry for Foreign Affairs (Sweden)|Ministry for Foreign Affairs]]. The agency was located in [[Stockholm]].
The Board's powers were similar to those of a [[court|court of law]]. It tried cases under the old Swedish Aliens Act of 1989 and the Swedish Citizenship Act. It also bore a responsibility for the development of [[case law]] in these areas. Its decisions could not be appealed, although in special cases the Board would submit an application to the [[Government of Sweden|Swedish Government]] for a decision.
The Aliens Appeals Board was discontinued and replaced by [[Migration Courts]] on 31 March 2006 when the new Aliens Act entered into force. The new rules of jurisdiction and procedure mean that individuals appealing against the decisions of the Swedish Migration Board (''[[Migrationsverket]]'') will be able to obtain an oral hearing in a Migration Court, in accordance with the provisions governing administrative courts. The opposite party in court proceedings will be the Swedish Migration Board.
==See also== *[[Government agencies in Sweden]].
==External links== *[http://www.domstol.se/ Swedish Courts] - Official site *[http://www.migrationsverket.se/ Swedish Migration Board] - Official Site
{{DEFAULTSORT:Aliens Appeals Board Of Sweden}} [[Category:Defunct government agencies of Sweden]] [[Category:Swedish labour law]] [[Category:Foreign relations of Sweden]] [[Category:Government agencies disestablished in 2006]] [[Category:Immigration law]] [[Category:Immigrants to Sweden]]
{{Sweden-gov-stub}} {{Europe-law-stub}}

{{Infobox military conflict |conflict=Battle of Verona |partof=the [[Roman-Germanic wars]] |image= |caption= |battle_name=Battle of Verona |date=30 September 489 |place=[[Verona]], modern {{ITA}} |result=Ostrogothic victory |combatant1=[[Heruls]]
[[Scirians]] |combatant2=[[Ostrogoths]]
[[Rugians]] |commander1=[[Odoacer]] |commander2=[[Theoderic the Great]] |strength1=20,000-25,000 |strength2=20,000 |casualties1=unknown |casualties2=unknown }} {{Campaignbox Conquest of Italy by Theodoric the Great}} The '''Battle of Verona''' was fought on 30 September 489 between the [[Ostrogoth]]ic leader [[Theoderic the Great]] and the [[Germanics|Germanic]] [[King of Italy]] [[Odoacer]]. Theoderic personally led his troops in battle, and achieved a decisive victory. Odoacer was subsequently forced to flee to [[Ravenna]], and Theoderic was free to capture [[Pavia]] and [[Milan]].{{cite book|author= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xsQxcJvaLjAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=History+of+the+Goths&hl=no&sa=X&ei=AAh-T_P3LsSp0QXB2-GVDg&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Bassianae%20Dengizich&f=false |title=History of the Goths |publisher=University of California Press |date=13 February 1990 |accessdate=5 April 2012}} {{coord missing|Italy}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} [[Category:480s conflicts|Verona 489]] [[Category:Battles involving the Ostrogoths|Verona 489]] [[Category:Battles involving Germanic peoples|Verona 489]] [[Category:Battles in Veneto]] [[Category:Ostrogothic Kingdom]] [[Category:489]] [[Category:5th century in Italy]] [[Category:History of Verona]] [[Category:Theoderic the Great]] {{Battle-stub}} {{Europe-hist-stub}}

[[File:Christian IX of Denmark with family (Tuxen).jpg|thumb|300px|King [[Christian IX of Denmark|Christian IX]] with his large family gathered at [[Fredensborg Palace]], painting by [[Laurits Tuxen]] from 1883 to 1886 ]] The '''Father-in-law of Europe''' is a [[sobriquet]] which has been used to refer to two [[Europe]]an [[monarch]]s of the late 19th and early 20th century: [[Christian IX of Denmark]] and [[Nicholas I of Montenegro]], both on account of their children's marriages to foreign princes and princesses. The fact that each was a monarch of moderate or modest power (and thus a marriage would not threaten the delicate [[Balance of power (international relations)|balance of power]]) allowed them to marry some of their many children to heirs of greater fortunes across the continent.
==Christian IX of Denmark== The children of [[King Christian IX of Denmark|King Christian IX]] (1818–1906) and [[Louise of Hesse-Kassel|Queen Louise]] (1817–1898) of Denmark included: * [[Frederick VIII of Denmark|King Frederick VIII of Denmark]] (1843–1912) * [[Queen Alexandra of the United Kingdom]] (1844–1925) queen consort of [[Edward VII|King Edward VII]] * [[King George I of Greece]] (1845–1913) * [[Maria Feodorovna (Dagmar of Denmark)|Empress Maria Feodorovna of Russia]] (1847–1928) empress consort of [[Alexander III of Russia|Tsar Alexander III]] * [[Thyra of Denmark|Crown Princess Thyra of Hanover]] (1853–1933), who married [[Ernest Augustus, Crown Prince of Hanover|Crown Prince Ernest Augustus]]
Christian IX used to gather his children, children-in-law and grandchildren for the so-called ''Fredensborg days'' at [[Fredensborg Palace]] north of [[Copenhagen]] in the summer time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dkks.dk/christian-9-med-familie-188/|title=Christian 9. med familie, 1886 |publisher=De Danske Kongers Kronologiske Samling|accessdate=2011-06-23}}</ref> Christian and Louise's grandchildren included [[George V|King George V of the United Kingdom]], [[Tsar Nicholas II of Russia]], [[Constantine I of Greece|King Constantine I of Greece]] and both [[King Haakon VII]] and his consort, [[Queen Maud of Norway]].
==Nicholas I of Montenegro== [[Nicholas I of Montenegro]] (1841–1921) was the father of: * [[Zorka of Montenegro]], who married King [[Peter I of Serbia]] * [[Elena of Montenegro]], who married King [[Victor Emmanuel III of Italy]] * [[Princess Anna of Montenegro|Anna of Montenegro]], who married [[Prince Francis Joseph of Battenberg]] * Two daughters who married brothers: ** [[Princess Anastasia of Montenegro|Anastasia of Montenegro]], who married [[Grand Duke Nicholas Nikolaevich of Russia (1856–1929)|Grand Duke Nicholas Nikolaevich of Russia]] after divorcing [[George Maximilianovich, 6th Duke of Leuchtenberg|George, Duke of Leuchtenberg]] ** [[Princess Milica of Montenegro|Milica of Montenegro]], who married [[Grand Duke Peter Nikolaevich of Russia]]
==See also== *[[Queen Victoria#Around the world|Queen Victoria]] was known as the ''grandmother of Europe''. *[[John William Friso, Prince of Orange]], the most recent ancestor of all current European royal houses **[[Royal descendants of John William Friso]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Europe, Father-In-Law Of}} [[Category:European royalty]]

Smilez | chronology = [[Camp Mulla]] | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = | misc = {{Singles | name = '''Funkytown''' | type = studio | single1 = [[Party Don't Stop]] | single1date = August 31, 2010 | single2 = Feel No Pain | single2date = October 22, 2011 | single3 = Fresh All Day | single3date = December 26, 2011 | single4 = Hold It Down | single4date = April 17, 2012 }} }} '''''Funky Town''''' (stylized '''FuNKYToWN''') is the debut [[studio album]] by [[Kenya]]n alternative hip hop group [[Camp Mulla]]. It was released on September 29, 2012.{{cite web |url=http://nairobi.hivisasa.com/entertainment/what-you-can-t-miss-camp-mulla-s-funky-town-launch |title=What you can’t miss: Camp Mulla’s ‘Funky Town’ launch |author=Steve Karathi |publisher=HiviSasa.com |date=21 September 2012 |accessdate=25 September 2012}} News of the album first came out on the group's [[WordPress]] blog on 17 April 2012, the same day the [[music video]] for "Hold It Down", the first single from the album, was released on [[YouTube]].[http://campmulla.wordpress.com/2012/04/17/camp-mulla-hold-it-down-254low-tribute-prod-by-k-cous/ Camp Mulla – Hold it Down (*254Low Tribute) Prod. by K’ Cous] - From the Camp Mulla WordPress Blog. Retrieved 22 April 2012.{{cite news |title=Camp Mulla hold it down in the CBD |url=http://www.capitalfm.co.ke/lifestyle/2012/04/18/camp-mulla-hold-it-down-in-the-cbd/ |publisher=Capital FM |location=Nairobi, Kenya |date=18 April 2012 |accessdate=22 April 2012}} The album gained wide publicity when Camp Mulla performed at the opening of the [[2012 Safari Sevens]] on September 22, 2012 to promote it. It was believed that the group had officially released their album during the performance.{{cite news |title=Camp Mulla Album Now In Stores |url=http://vibeweekly.com/home/news/2865-camp-mulla-album-now-in-stores.html |publisher=Vibe Weekly |date=25 September 2012 |accessdate=29 September 2012}}{{cite news |title=Camp Mulla Release Debut Album at Safaricom Sevens |url=http://www.ghafla.co.ke/news/music/item/4247-camp-mulla-release-debut-album-at-safaricom-sevens |publisher=Ghafla! News |date=25 September 2012 |accessdate=29 September 2012}} ==Track listing==

{{Refimprove|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox Political Party |name = Gibraltar Labour Party |logo = |leader = [[Daniel Feetham]] |foundation = 2003 |dissolved = 2005 |ideology = [[Progressivism]]
[[Social democracy]] |position = [[Centre-left]] |international = |european = |europarl = |colours = |headquarters = |website = |split = [[Gibraltar Socialist Labour Party]] |merged = [[Gibraltar Social Democrats]] |colorcode = #FF0000 |country=Gibraltar}} {{Politics of Gibraltar}} The '''Gibraltar Labour Party''' was a [[political party]] in [[Gibraltar]]. They described themselves as a [[progressivism|progressive]] [[socialism|socialist]] organisation and stated that their formation was prompted by the need for a strong opposition to the government. They were founded and led by [[Daniel Feetham]], who left the [[Gibraltar Socialist Labour Party]]. [[Image:Daniel Feetham.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Ex-leader of the Gibraltar Labour Party, [[Daniel Feetham]]]] They opposed dialogue with [[Spain]] and wanted to change the [[Constitution of Gibraltar]], and support the right of Gibraltarians to decide their own constitutional arrangements under the principle of [[self-determination]]. They were also in favour of further integration with the United Kingdom. They had proposed policies for the improvement of the quality and availability of [[house|housing]] in Gibraltar. They proposed that no individual should serve as [[Chief Minister of Gibraltar|Chief Minister]] for more than two terms, and called for a more transparent form of [[campaign finance|funding]] of political parties. ==Elections== In the [[Gibraltar general election, 2003|2003 General Election]] to the [[Gibraltar Parliament|Gibraltar House of Assembly]], the party won 9,445 votes [http://www.parliament.gi/images/parliamentary_election_statistics/general_election_results_by_party_independents_in_percentage_terms.pdf (or 8.0% of the popular vote)] and no seats. This is the '''largest''' number of votes (in terms of both percentage and actual number of votes) for a Gibraltarian political party that has '''not''' won a seat in the Legislature '''throughout its electoral history'''. ==Election results== ===''[[Gibraltar Parliament|Parliament of Gibraltar]]''=== {| class=wikitable style=text-align:center ! Election year ! # of
overall votes ! % of
overall vote ! # of
overall seats won ! ± |- ! [[Gibraltar general election, 2003|2003]] | 9,445 | 8.0 | {{Composition bar|0|15|hex=#01789a}} | New |- |} ==Merger== In 2005, the Labour Party merged with the governing [[Gibraltar Social Democrats]], retaining the GSD name and leadership.http://thegibraltarchronicle.blogspot.com/search?q=Labour+Party This move was deeply unpopular with many, especially within the GSD, and caused many high-profile members to leave, including GSD Deputy Leader and former Deputy Chief Minister [[Keith Azopardi]] and executive member [[Nick Cruz]], who both went on to form the [[Progressive Democratic Party (Gibraltar)|Progressive Democratic Party]] in 2006. ==References== {{Gibraltar political parties}} [[Category:Labour parties]] [[Category:Defunct political parties in Gibraltar]] [[Category:Political parties established in 2003]] [[Category:2003 establishments in Gibraltar]] [[Category:Political parties disestablished in 2005]] [[Category:Socialism in Gibraltar]] {{Gibraltar-party-stub}}

{{unreferenced|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Portugal}} "Há sempre alguém" | image = | caption = | year = 1990 | country = Portugal | artist = Cristina Baldaia | as = Nucha | with = | language = Portuguese | languages = | composer = Luís Filipe, Jan van Dijck | lyricist = Francisco Pereira,
Frederico Pereira | conductor = Carlos Alberto Moniz | place = 20th | points = 9 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1990pt from Diggiloo Thrush] | clip = | prev = Conquistador | prev_link = Conquistador (Da Vinci song) | next = Lusitana paixão | next_link = Lusitana paixão }} '''"Há sempre alguém"''' ("There's always someone") was the [[Portugal|Portuguese]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1990]], performed in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] by [[Nucha (singer)|Nucha]]. In the song, Nucha reminds her listeners that "There's always someone/Who still doesn't have as much as we do" but who also dreams the same dreams that the better-off members of society do. The song was performed sixteenth on the night, following [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]]'s [[Tatiana Cameron|Tajči]] with "[[Hajde da ludujemo]]" and preceding [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]'s [[Liam Reilly]] with "[[Somewhere in Europe (song)|Somewhere in Europe]]". At the close of voting, it had received 9 points, placing 20th in a field of 22. It was succeeded as [[Portugal in the Eurovision Song Contest|Portuguese representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1991|1991 Contest]] by [[Dulce Pontes|Dulce]] with "[[Lusitana paixão]]". {{Eurovision Song Contest 1990}} {{Portugal in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ha Sempre Alguem}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of Portugal]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1990]] [[Category:Portuguese-language songs]] [[Category:1990 songs]] {{portugal-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Accounting}}
'''IFRS 9''' is an [[International Financial Reporting Standard]] (IFRS) promulgated by the [[International Accounting Standards Board]] (IASB). It addresses the accounting for [[financial instrument]]s. It contains three main topics: classification and measurement of financial instruments, [[Revaluation of fixed assets|impairment]] of [[financial asset]]s and [[hedge accounting]]. It will replace the earlier IFRS for financial instruments, [[IAS 39]], when it becomes effective in 2018. However, early adoption is allowed.
==History== IFRS 9 began as a joint project with the [[Financial Accounting Standards Board]] (FASB), which promulgates accounting standards in the United States. The boards published a joint discussion paper in March 2008 proposing an eventual goal of reporting all financial instruments at [[fair value]], with all changes in fair value reported in [[net income]] (FASB) or [[net income|profit and loss]] (IASB).<ref>{{cite web|title=Reducing Complexity in Reporting Financial Instruments|url=http://www.fasb.org/cs/BlobServer?blobkey=id&blobnocache=true&blobwhere=1175827496152&blobheader=application%2Fpdf&blobheadername2=Content-Length&blobheadername1=Content-Disposition&blobheadervalue2=803637&blobheadervalue1=filename%3DITC_Financial_Instruments.pdf&blobcol=urldata&blobtable=MungoBlobs|publisher=[[FASB]]|accessdate=2014-08-31|date=March 2008}}</ref> As a result of the [[financial crisis of 2008]], the boards decided to revise their accounting standards for financial instruments to address perceived deficiencies which were believed to have contributed to the magnitude of the crisis.<ref name=ifrs9>{{cite web|title=IFRS 9 Financial Instruments (replacement of IAS 39)|url=http://www.ifrs.org/current-projects/iasb-projects/financial-instruments-a-replacement-of-ias-39-financial-instruments-recognitio/Pages/financial-instruments-replacement-of-ias-39.aspx|publisher=[[IASB]]|accessdate=2014-08-31}}</ref>
The boards disagreed on several important issues, and also took different approaches to developing the new financial instruments standard.<ref name=insurance/> FASB attempted to develop a comprehensive standard that would address classification and measurement, impairment and hedge accounting at the same time, and issued an exposure draft of a standard addressing all three components in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=Accounting for Financial Instruments and Revisions to the Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities|url=http://www.fasb.org/cs/BlobServer?blobkey=id&blobnocache=true&blobwhere=1175823559151&blobheader=application%2Fpdf&blobheadername2=Content-Length&blobheadername1=Content-Disposition&blobheadervalue2=842688&blobheadervalue1=filename%3DProposed_ASU_Derivatives_and_Hedging__Topic_815___and_Financial_Instruments__Topic_825_.pdf&blobcol=urldata&blobtable=MungoBlobs|date=May 2010|publisher=[[FASB]]|accessdate=2014-08-31}}</ref><ref name=insurance>{{cite news|title=GAAP/IFRS Accounting Projects—More Than Just Insurance Contracts|author=Reback, L.J.|pages=12–14|newspaper=The Financial Reporter|publisher=[[Society of Actuaries]]|date=December 2011}}</ref> In contrast, the IASB attempted to develop the new standard in phases, releasing each component of the new standard separately.<ref name=insurance/><ref name=kpmg1>{{cite web|title=First Impressions: IFRS 9 Financial Instruments|publisher=[[KPMG]]|url=http://www.kpmg.com/Global/en/IssuesAndInsights/ArticlesPublications/first-impressions/Documents/First-Impressions-IFRS-9-Financial-Instruments.pdf|date=December 2009|accessdate=2014-08-31}}</ref> In 2009, IASB issued the first portion of IFRS, covering classification and measurement of financial assets.<ref name=kpmg1/><ref name=deloitte1>{{cite news|title=IASB issues IFRS 9 'Financial Instruments'|publisher=[[Deloitte]]|url=http://www.iasplus.com/en/news/2009/November/news5269|date=12 November 2009|accessdate=2014-08-31}}</ref> This was intended to replace the asset classification and measurement sections of IAS 39, but not supersede other sections of IAS 39.<ref name=kpmg1/><ref name=deloitte1/> In 2010, IASB issued another portion of IFRS 9, primarily covering classification and measurement of financial liabilities and also addressing aspects of applying [[fair value option]] and bifurcating [[derivative (finance)|embedded derivatives]].<ref name=kpmg2>{{cite web|title=First Impressions: Additions to IFRS 9 Financial Instruments|url=http://www.kpmg.com/Global/en/IssuesAndInsights/ArticlesPublications/first-impressions/Documents/IFRS-9-additions-dec-2010.pdf|publisher=[[KPMG]]|date=December 2010|accessdate=2014-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=IASB issues additions to IFRS 9 for financial liability accounting|publisher=[[Deloitte]]|url=http://www.iasplus.com/en/news/2010/October/news6194|date=28 October 2010|accessdate=2014-08-31}}</ref>
Certain elements of IFRS 9 as issued were criticized by some key IASB constituents. The model for classifying [[debt|debt instrument]] assets permitted only two approaches, fair value with all changes in fair value reported in profit and loss (FVPL), or [[amortized cost]].<ref name=2012ed/> This represented a significant deviation from FASB decisions, which would also have a category of fair value with certain changes in fair value reported in [[other comprehensive income]] (FVOCI).<ref name=insurance/> In addition to creating significant divergence with FASB, the lack of a FVOCI category would have been inconsistent with the accounting model being developed by the IASB for insurance contracts.<ref name=2012ed/><ref name=ey/><ref name=insurance/> There were also concerns that the criteria for qualifying for the amortized cost category were overly stringent and would force many financial instruments to be reported at fair value even though they could be appropriately accounted for at amortized cost.<ref name=2012ed/> To address these concerns, IASB issued an exposure draft in 2012 proposing limited amendments to the classification and measurement of financial instruments.<ref name=2012ed>{{cite web|title=Exposure Draft and Comment letters 2012|url=http://www.ifrs.org/Current-Projects/IASB-Projects/Financial-Instruments-A-Replacement-of-IAS-39-Financial-Instruments-Recognitio/Limited-modifications-to-IFRS-9/Exposure-Draft-and-comment-letters-Nov-2012/Pages/ED-and-CL-November-2012.aspx|publisher=[[IASB]]|date=November 2012|accessdate=2014-08-31}}</ref>
Meanwhile, IASB and FASB worked together to develop a model for impairment of financial assets. IASB issued an exposure draft proposing an impairment model in 2013.<ref name=impairment>{{cite web|title=Exposure Draft and Comment letters|url=http://www.ifrs.org/Current-Projects/IASB-Projects/Financial-Instruments-A-Replacement-of-IAS-39-Financial-Instruments-Recognitio/Impairment/Exposure-Draft-March-2013/Pages/ED-and-Comment-letters.aspx|publisher=[[IASB]]|date=March 2013|accessdate=2014-08-31}}</ref> FASB decided to propose an alternative impairment model.<ref name=impairment/> IASB was also developing its hedge accounting model independently of FASB, and issued that portion of the IFRS 9 standard in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=IASB completes important steps in reform of financial instruments accounting|date=19 November 2013|publisher=[[IASB]]|url=http://www.ifrs.org/Current-Projects/IASB-Projects/Financial-Instruments-A-Replacement-of-IAS-39-Financial-Instruments-Recognitio/Phase-III-Hedge-accounting/Project-news/Pages/Project-update-November-2013.aspx|accessdate=2014-08-31}}</ref> The final IFRS 9 standard, including hedge accounting, impairment, and the amended classification and measurement guidance, was issued on 24 July 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=IASB completes reform of financial instruments accounting|url=http://www.ifrs.org/Alerts/PressRelease/Pages/IASB-completes-reform-of-financial-instruments-accounting-July-2014.aspx|date=24 July 2014|publisher=[[IASB]]|accessdate=2014-08-31}}</ref>
Early evidence on the market reaction to the IFRS 9 in Europe suggests overall a positive response to the IFRS 9, although heterogeneities across countries exist.<ref name=JAPP2014>{{cite journal|title= Onali, E.; Ginesti, G. (2014). Pre-adoption market reaction to IFRS 9: A cross-country event study. ''Journal of Accounting and Public Policy'', forthcoming | url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0278425414000696 | doi=10.1016/j.jaccpubpol.2014.08.004 | volume=33 | issue=6 | journal=Journal of Accounting and Public Policy | pages=628–637| date=November 2014 | last1=Onali | first1=Enrico | last2=Ginesti | first2=Gianluca }}</ref>
==Classification and measurement== As amended, IFRS 9 had four possible classification categories for financial assets, including a FVOCI classification for debt instruments.<ref name=ey>{{cite web|title=IASB issues IFRS 9 Financial Instruments – classification and measurement|url=http://www.ey.com/Publication/vwLUAssets/EY-ifrs-developments-issue-86-july2014/$File/EY-ifrs-developments-issue-86-july2014.pdf|publisher=[[Ernst & Young]]|date=July 2014|accessdate=2014-08-31}}</ref> The classification is dependent on two tests, a contractual cash flow test (named SPPI as Solely Payments of Principal and Interest) and a business model assessment.<ref name=ey/><ref name=dt>{{cite news|title=IASB publishes final version of IFRS 9|url=http://www.iasplus.com/en-us/news/2014/07/ifrs-9|publisher=[[Deloitte]]|date=24 July 2014|accessdate=2014-08-31}}</ref> Unless the asset meets the requirements of both tests, it is measured at fair value with all changes in fair value reporting in profit and loss (FVPL).<ref name=ey/> In order to meet the contractual cash flow test, the cash flows from the instrument must consist of only [[principal (finance)|principal]] and [[interest]].<ref name=ey/> Among the amendments to classification and measurement made in the 2014 update, ''de minimis'' and "non-genuine" features can be disregarded from the test, meaning that a ''de minimis'' feature would not preclude an instrument from being reported at amortized cost or FVOCI.<ref name=ey/> However, [[equity (finance)|equity]] instruments, [[derivative (finance)|derivatives]] and instruments that contain other than ''de minimis'' embedded derivatives would have to be reported at FVPL.<ref name=ey/>
If the asset passes the contractual cash flows test, the business model assessment determines how the instrument is classified. If the instrument is being held to collect contractual cash flows, i.e., it is not expected to be sold, it is classified as amortized cost.<ref name=ey/> If the business model for the instrument is to both collect contractual cash flows and potentially sell the asset, it is reported at FVOCI.<ref name=ey/><ref name=dt/> For a FVOCI asset, the amortized cost basis is used to determine profit and loss, but the asset is reported at fair value on the [[balance sheet]], with the difference between amortized cost and fair value reported in [[other comprehensive income]].<ref name=dt/> For any other business model, such as holding the asset for trading, the asset is reported at FVPL.<ref name=ey/>
IFRS 9 retained most of the measurement guidance for liabilities from IAS 39, meaning most financial liabilities are held at amortized cost,<ref name=ey/> the only change relating to liabilities that utilize the fair value option.<ref name=ey/> For those liabilities, the change in fair value related to the entity's own credit standing is reported in other comprehensive income rather than profit and loss.<ref name=ey/>
IFRS 9 retained the concept of fair value option from IAS 39, but revised the criteria for financial assets.<ref name=ey/><ref name=dt/> Under a fair value option, an asset or liability that would otherwise be reported at amortized cost or FVOCI can use FVPL instead. IFRS 9 also incorporated a FVOCI option for certain equity instruments that are not held for trading.<ref name=ey/> Under this option, the instrument is reported at FVOCI similar to FVOCI for debt. However, this version of FVOCI does not permit "recycling."<ref name=ey/> Whereas when debt instruments using FVOCI are sold, the gain or loss on sale is "recycled" from other comprehensive income to profit and loss,<ref name=dt/> for FVOCI equities the gain or loss is never reported in profit and loss, but rather remains in other comprehensive income.
==Impairment== IFRS 9 requires an impairment allowance against the amortized cost of financial assets held at amortized cost or FVOCI.<ref name=dt/> The change in this allowance is reported in profit and loss.<ref name=dt/> For most such assets, when the asset is acquired the impairment allowance is measured as the [[present value]] of credit losses from default events projected over the next 12 months.<ref name=dt/> The allowance remains based on the expected losses from defaults over the next 12 months unless there is a significant increase in credit risk.<ref name=dt/> If there is a significant increase in credit risk, the allowance is measured as the present value of all credit losses projected for the instrument over its full lifetime.<ref name=dt/> If the credit risk recovers, the allowance can once again be limited to the projected credit losses over the next 12 months.<ref name=kpmg3>{{cite web|title=Financial instruments - the complete standard|url=http://www.kpmg.com/Global/en/IssuesAndInsights/ArticlesPublications/In-the-Headlines/Documents/ITH-2014-13.pdf|publisher=[[KPMG]]|date=July 2014|accessdate=2014-08-31}}</ref>
An exception to the general impairment model applies to financial assets that are credit impaired when they were originally acquired.<ref name=dt/> For these assets, the impairment allowance is always based on the change in projected lifetime credit losses since the asset was acquired.<ref name=dt/>
The new impairment model is intended to address a criticism of the impairment model used during the financial crisis, that it allowed companies to delay recognition of asset impairments.<ref name=ifrs9/> The new model requires recognition of full lifetime losses more quickly,<ref name=ifrs9/> FASB elected to use a different approach to accelerating recognition of impairment losses, requiring full lifetime recognition from the time the asset is acquired, referred to as the "current expected credit losses" or CECL model.<ref>{{cite web|title=Accounting for Financial Instruments—Credit Impairment—Joint Project of the FASB and IASB|url=http://www.fasb.org/jsp/FASB/FASBContent_C/ProjectUpdatePage&cid=1176159268094|publisher=[[FASB]]|accessdate=2014-08-31}}</ref> Under both IFRS 9 and the FASB model there will be a loss when most assets covered by this guidance are acquired to the extent of the allowance.<ref name=insurance2>{{cite news|title=FASB and IASB Divergence|author=Reback, L.J.|date=June 2014|newspaper=The Financial Reporter|publisher=[[Society of Actuaries]]|pages=22–24}}</ref> This loss will be smaller under the IFRS 9 model, due to the 12 month limit.<ref name=insurance2/>
==Hedge accounting== IFRS 9 updated the guidance for hedge accounting. The intent was to "[align] the accounting treatment with risk management activities, enabling entities to reflect better these activities in their financial statements."<ref name=ifrs9/> The changes also make it more feasible for non-financial entities to use hedge accounting.<ref name=ey2>{{cite web|title=Hedge accounting under IFRS 9|url=http://www.ey.com/Publication/vwLUAssets/Applying_IFRS:_Hedge_accounting_under_IFRS_9/$File/Applying_Hedging_Feb2014.pdf|publisher=[[Ernst & Young]]|date=February 2014|accessdate=2014-08-31}}</ref> The changes permit more use of hedge accounting for components of instruments and groups of contracts, and ease the hedge effectiveness test.<ref name=ey2/> They also enhance the disclosures related to hedges and risk management with a requirement to refer to a formal risk management strategy or describe it clearly in the hedge documentation.<ref name=ifrs9/><ref name=ey2/>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{primary sources|date=December 2011}} {{Refimprove|date=September 2009}} {{Infobox organization |name = International Association for Suicide Prevention |image = |image_border = |size = |alt = |caption = IASP |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |abbreviation = IASP |motto = |formation = 1960 |extinction = |type = [[International nongovernmental organization|INGO]] |status = |purpose = |headquarters = |location = |region_served = Worldwide |membership = |language = English |leader_title = President |leader_name = |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.iasp.info/ IASP Official website] |remarks = }} The '''International Association for Suicide Prevention''' (IASP) is an international [[suicide prevention]] organization. Founded by [[Erwin Ringel]] and [[Norman Farberow]] in 1960, IASP, which is in an official relationship with the [[World Health Organization]], is dedicated to preventing suicidal behaviour and providing a forum for mental health professionals, crisis workers, [[suicide survivor]]s and other people in one way or another affected by suicidal behaviour. The organization now consists of professionals and volunteers from over 50 countries worldwide. The IASP also co-sponsors [[World Suicide Prevention Day]] on September 10 every year, with the World Health Organization. ==IASP Congresses== The IASP holds international congresses every two years. XXIX World Congress of the IASP will be organized in [[Kuching]] (Malaysia) in 2017.https://www.iasp.info/congresses.php Past congresses 2015 Montreal, Canada
2013 Oslo, Norway(http://www.iasp2013.org/index.php)
2011 Beijing, Chinahttp://www.iaspchina.org/
2009 Montevideo, Uruguay
2007 Killarney, Ireland

1997 Adelaide, Australia

1960 Vienna, Austria
==Awards== The International Association for Suicide Prevention (IASP) provides [http://www.iasp.info/awards.php awards] for those who have contributed in a significant way to the furthering of the aims of the Association. Awards are presented at the IASP biennial conference. The '''Stengel Research Award''' has been provided since 1977 and is named in honour of the late Professor Erwin Stengel, one of the founders of the International Association for Suicide Prevention (IASP). This award is for outstanding research in the field of suicidology, and nominations can be made by any member of IASP. The '''Ringel Service Award''' was instituted in 1995 and honours the late Professor Erwin Ringel, the founding President of the Association. This award is for distinguished service in the field of suicidology, and nominations can be made by National Representatives of IASP. The '''Farberow Award''' was introduced in 1997 in recognition of Professor Norman Farberow, a founding member and driving force behind the IASP. This award is for a person who has contributed significantly in the field of work with survivors of suicide, and nominations can be made by any IASP member. The '''De Leo Fund Award''' honours the memory of Nicola and Vittorio, the beloved children of Professor Diego De Leo, IASP Past President. The Award is offered to distinguished scholars in recognition of their outstanding research on suicidal behaviours carried out in developing countries. ==Journal== The Association’s journal, ''[[Crisis - The Journal of Crisis Intervention and Suicide Prevention]]'', has been published since 1980.http://www.hogrefe.com/periodicals/crisis-the-journal-of-crisis-intervention-and-suicide-prevention/ ==References== ==External links== * [http://www.iasp.info/ International Association for Suicide Prevention (IASP) - Official Website] {{DEFAULTSORT:International Association For Suicide Prevention}} [[Category:International medical and health organizations]] [[Category:Mental health organizations in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1960]] [[Category:Suicide prevention]]

{{Infobox station | name = [[File:Sofia Metro Logo.svg|30px|left|link=Sofia Metro]] Joliot-Curie | type = | style = Sofia Metro | image = Joliot-Curie Metrostation.jpg | image_caption = | address = | coordinates = {{Coord|42|40|17|N|23|21|03|E|type:railwaystation_region:BG-23|display=inline,title}} | line = <!-- line information is detailed under "services" --> | other = | structure = sub-surface | platform = side | depth = | levels = 2 | tracks = 2 | parking = Yes | bicycle = | baggage_check = | opened = 8-May-2009 | closed = | rebuilt = | electrified = | ADA = | code = 3019; 3020 | owned = [[Sofia#Administration|Sofia Municipality]] | zone = | smartcardname = | smartcardstatus = | former = [[Interpred World Trade Center Sofia]] | passengers = | pass_year = | pass_percent = | pass_system = | mpassengers = | services = {{s-rail|title=Sofia Metro}} {{s-line|system=Sofia Metro|line=Line 1|previous=Vasil Levski stadium|next=G.M.Dimitrov}} {{s-line|system=Sofia Metro|line=Line 2|previous=Vasil Levski stadium|next=G.M.Dimitrov}} | map_locator = [[File:Map8 eng trans.png|300px]] | web = }} {{Sofia Metro Red line}} {{Sofia Metro Blue line}} '''Joliot-Curie Metro Station''' ({{lang-bg|Метростанция "Жолио Кюри"}}) is a station on the [[Sofia Metro]] in [[Bulgaria]]. It was put into operation on May 8, 2009.<ref>http://www.novinite.com/view_news.php?id=103398</ref>
==Public Transportation== * [[Public buses in Sofia|City Bus service]]: 413 * [[Public buses in Sofia|Suburban Bus service]]: 67
==Location== The station is under [[Dragan Tsankov Boulevard]] at the intersection with Frederic Joliot-Curie Str. It is located next to the [[Interpred World Trade Center Sofia|World Trade Center - Sofia]], near the Russian Embassy.
The station serves Iztok and Izgrev residential districts and the Southern Bus Station. It is defined by a central entrance vestibule with underpass links to both sides of the boulevard and the surrounding residential areas.
The entrance vestibule and ramp of the station are covered with granite tiles and have suspended ceilings. The entire station was designed in vibrant colors: the platforms are covered with colored granite tiles and the walls have panels of circular red mosaic designs set on white tiles. The walls behind the panels are covered with a light blue mosaic.
Because of the route specifics, the station's platforms enter a maximum curve.

{{Infobox former subdivision |conventional_long_name = Kingdom of Sicily |common_name = Sicily |native_name = ''Regnum Siciliae'' {{la icon}}
''Regnu di Sicilia'' {{scn icon}}
''Regno di Sicilia'' {{it icon}} |status_text = [[Personal union]]s with:{{plainlist| *the [[Holy Roman Empire]] (1194–1254)
{{small|(also with the [[Kingdom of Jerusalem]]: 1225–1228)}} *the [[Crown of Aragon]] (1412–1516) *the [[Habsburg Spain|Kingdom of Spain]] (1516–1713) *the [[Duchy of Savoy]] (1713–1720) *the [[Habsburg Monarchy]] (1720–1735) *the [[Kingdom of Naples]] (1735–1806)}} |image_flag = Bandiera del Regno di Sicilia 4.svg |image_coat = Coat of Arms SICILY.svg |image_map = Kingdom of Sicily.jpg |image_map_caption = The Kingdom of Sicily with its territorial evolution | |today = {{plainlist| *{{ITA}} *{{MLT}} *{{TUN}} *{{LBY}} *{{GRE}} *{{ALB}}}} |government_type = Feudal monarchy | |event_start = [[Roger II of Sicily#Royal investiture|Coronation of Roger]] |year_start = 1130 |event_end = [[Kingdom of the Two Sicilies|Two Sicilies]] |date_end = |year_end = 1816 |event2 = [[Sicilian Vespers]] |date_event2 = 1282 |event_post = |date_post = | |p1 = County of Sicily |image_p1 = [[File:Coat of Arms of Roger I of Sicily.svg|20px]] |p2 = County of Apulia |image_p2 = [[File:Coat of Arms of Robert Guiscard.svg|20px]] |p3 = Zirid dynasty |image_p3 = [[File:Zirids around 1000CE.png|20px]] |s1 = Kingdom of the Two Sicilies |flag_s1 = Flag of the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies (1816).svg | |capital = {{ubl| [[Palermo]] (1130–1816)}} | |national_motto = |national_anthem = |leader1 = [[Roger II of Sicily|Roger II]] |year_leader1 = 1130–1154 |leader2 = [[Charles I of Naples|Charles I of Anjou]] |year_leader2 = 1266–1282 |leader3 = [[Ferdinand I of the Two Sicilies|Ferdinand III]] |year_leader3 = 1759–1816 |title_leader = [[List of monarchs of Sicily|King]] |footnotes = }} The '''Kingdom of Sicily''' ({{lang-la|Regnum Siciliae}}, {{lang-it|Regno di Sicilia}}, {{lang-scn|Regnu di Sicilia}},{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XSNSAQAAMAAJ&lpg=PR32&ots=cpw04L1BGk&dq=regnu%2520di%2520sicilia&pg=PR32#v=onepage&q=regnu%2520di%2520sicilia&f=false|title=Documenti per servire alla storia di Sicilia: Diplomatica|date=1891-01-01|publisher=U. Manfredi Editori|language=it}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rYg74wTJS7oC&lpg=PA314&ots=k8O9fpCmqI&dq=regnu%2520di%2520sicilia&pg=PA314#v=onepage&q=regnu%2520di%2520sicilia&f=false|title=Felicis, et fidelissimæ urbis Panormitanæ selecta aliquot ad civitatis decus, et commodum spectantia privilegia per instrumenta varia Siciliæ ... opera don Michaelis De Vio ..|last=Vio|first=Michele Del|date=1706-01-01|publisher=in palatio senatorio per Dominicum Cortese|language=it}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hqANAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA303&ots=E_2s9y6n7p&dq=regnu%2520di%2520sicilia&pg=PA303#v=onepage&q=regnu%2520di%2520sicilia&f=false|title=Considerazioni sopra la storia di Sicilia dai tempi normanni sino al presenti|last=Gregorio|first=Rosario|date=1833-01-01|publisher=dalla Reale Stamperia|language=it}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CW9UAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA109&ots=1iTBXJlTwn&dq=regnu%2520di%2520sicilia&pg=PA109#v=onepage&q=regnu%2520di%2520sicilia&f=false|title=Parlamenti generali del regno di Sicilia dall' anno 1446 sino al 1748: con le memorie istoriche dell' antico, e moderno uso del parlamento appresso varie nazioni, ed in particolare della sua origine in Sicilia, e del modo di celebrarsi|last=Mongitore|first=Antonino|last2=Mongitore|first2=Francesco Serio e|date=1749-01-01|publisher=Presso P. Bentivenga|language=it}} {{lang-ca|Regne de Sicília}}, {{lang-es|Reino de Sicilia}}) was a state that existed in the south of the [[Italian peninsula]] and for a time [[Kingdom of Africa|the region of Ifriqiya]] from its founding by [[Roger II of Sicily|Roger II]] in 1130 until 1816. It was a successor state of the [[County of Sicily]], which had been founded in 1071 during the [[Norman conquest of southern Italy|Norman conquest of the southern peninsula]]. The island was divided into [[Three valli of Sicily|three regions]]: Val di Mazara, Val Demone and Val di Noto; 'val' being the Arabic word meaning 'district'. In 1282, a revolt against [[Capetian House of Anjou|Angevin]] rule, known as the [[Sicilian Vespers]], threw off [[Charles of Anjou]]'s rule of the island of Sicily. The Angevins managed to maintain control in the mainland part of the kingdom, which became a separate entity also styled ''Kingdom of Sicily'', although it is commonly referred to as the [[Kingdom of Naples]], after its capital. The island became a separate kingdom under the [[Crown of Aragon]]. After 1302 the island kingdom was sometimes called the '''Kingdom of Trinacria'''.{{Cite book|author=N. Zeldes |title=The former Jews of this kingdom: Sicilian converts after the Expulsion, 1492–1516 |year=2003 |pages=5, 69, 296–97|publisher=BRILL |isbn=90-04-12898-0}} Often the kingship was vested in another monarch such as the [[King of Aragon]], the [[King of Spain]], or the [[Holy Roman Emperor]]. In 1816 the island Kingdom of Sicily merged with the Kingdom of Naples to form the [[Kingdom of the Two Sicilies]]. In 1861 the Two Sicilies were amalgamated with Sardinia and several northern city-states and duchies to form the [[Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)|Kingdom of Italy]]. == History == ===Norman conquest=== {{main|Emirate of Sicily|Norman conquest of southern Italy}} By the 11th century mainland southern [[Duchy of Benevento|Lombard]] and [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] powers were hiring Norman mercenaries, who were descendants of the [[Vikings]]; it was the Normans under [[Roger I of Sicily|Roger I]] who conquered Sicily, taking it away from the Arab Muslims. After taking [[Apulia]] and [[Calabria]], Roger occupied [[Messina]] with an army of 700 knights. In 1068, [[Roger I of Sicily]] and his men defeated the Muslims at [[Misilmeri]] but the most crucial battle was the siege of Palermo, which led to Sicily being completely under Norman control by 1091.{{cite news|url=http://www.initaly.com/regions/sicily/chronol.htm|publisher=In Italy Magazine|title=Chronological - Historical Table Of Sicily|date=7 October 2007}} === Norman kingdom === {{See also|Roger II of Sicily|Kingdom of Africa}} {{multiple image | direction = vertical | width = 235 | footer = | image1 = Roger II Sicily.jpg | alt1 = | caption1 = [[Roger II of Sicily|Roger II]], the first king of Sicily. | image2 = Weltliche Schatzkammer Wienc.jpg | alt2 = | caption2 = The royal mantle. | image3 = Scribes 01 Kingdom of Sicily Petrus de Ebulo.PNG | alt3 = | caption3 = Scribes of and for the various populations of the Kingdom of Sicily: Greeks, Saracens, Latins. }} [[File:Regnonormanno1160.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Maximal expansion of the Kingdom of Sicily.]] The [[Italo-Normans|Norman]] Kingdom was created on Christmas Day, 1130, by [[Roger II of Sicily|Roger II of Sicily]], with the agreement of [[Pope Innocent II]], who united the lands Roger had inherited from his father [[Roger I of Sicily|Roger I of Sicily]].Douglas, David. ''The Norman Fate, 1100-1154''. Los Angeles: [[University of California Press]], 1976. These areas included the [[Malta (island)|Maltese Archipelago]], which was conquered from the [[Emirate of Sicily|Arabs of the Emirates of Sicily]]; the [[Duchy of Apulia]] and the [[County of Sicily]], which had belonged to his cousin [[William II, Duke of Apulia|William II, Duke of Apulia]], until William's death in 1127; and the other Norman vassals. Roger threw his support behind the [[Antipope Anacletus II|Antipope Anacletus II]], who enthroned him as King of Sicily on Christmas Day 1130.{{Cite book|last=Houben |first=Hubert |title=Roger II of Sicily: A Ruler between East and West |year=2002|pages=7, 148 |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|isbn=0-521-65573-0}} In 1136, the rival of Anacletus, [[Pope Innocent II|Pope Innocent II]], convinced [[Lothair III, Holy Roman Emperor|Lothair III, Holy Roman Emperor]] to attack the Kingdom of Sicily with help from the [[Byzantine Emperor]] [[John II Comnenus|John II Comnenus]]. Two main armies, one led by Lothair, the other by [[Duke of Bavaria]] [[Henry the Proud]], invaded Sicily. On the river [[Tronto]], [[William of Loritello]] surrendered to Lothair and opened the gates of Termoli to him. This was followed by Count Hugh II of Molise. The two armies were united at [[Bari]], from where in 1137 they continued their campaign. Roger offered to give Apulia as a [[fief]] to the Empire, which Lothair refused after being pressured by Innocent. At the same period the army of Lothair revolted. Then Lothair, who had hoped for the complete conquest of Sicily, gave [[Capua]] and Apulia from the Kingdom of Sicily to Roger's enemies. Innocent protested, claiming that Apulia fell under papal claims. Lothair turned north, but died while crossing the Alps on December 4, 1137. At the [[Second Council of the Lateran]] in April 1139, Innocent excommunicated Roger for maintaining a [[Schism (religion)|schismatic]] attitude. On March 22, 1139, at Galluccio, Roger's son [[Roger III, Duke of Apulia|Roger III, Duke of Apulia]] ambushed the papal troops with a thousand knights and captured the pope.{{Cite book|author=Malcolm Barber |title=The two cities: medieval Europe, 1050–1320 |year=2004 |page=211 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=0-415-17414-7 }} On March 25, 1139, Innocent was forced to acknowledge the kingship and possessions of Roger with the [[Treaty of Mignano]]. Roger spent most of the decade, beginning with his coronation and ending with the [[Assizes of Ariano]], enacting a series of laws with which Roger intended to centralise the government, fending off multiple invasions and quelling rebellions by his premier vassals: [[Grimoald of Bari]], [[Robert II of Capua|Robert II of Capua]], [[Ranulf of Alife]], [[Sergius VII of Naples|Sergius VII of Naples]] and others. It was through his admiral [[George of Antioch]] that Roger then proceeded to conquer the littoral of [[Ifriqiya]] from the [[Zirid dynasty|Zirids]], taking the unofficial title "[[Kingdom of Africa|King of Africa]]" and marking the foundation of the Norman Kingdom of Africa. At the same time Roger's fleet also attacked the [[Byzantine Empire]], making Sicily a leading maritime power in the [[Mediterranean Sea]] for almost a century. Roger's son and successor was [[William I of Sicily|William I of Sicily]], known as "William the Bad", though his nickname derived primarily from his lack of popularity with the chroniclers, who supported the baronial revolts which William suppressed. In the mid-1150s, William lost the majority of his African possessions to a series of revolts from local North African lords. Then, in 1160, the final Norman African stronghold of Mahdia was taken by [[Almohads]]. His reign ended in peace (1166), but with his elder son [[Roger IV, Duke of Apulia|Roger]] killed in previous revolts, his son, [[William II of Sicily|William II]], was a minor. Until the end of the boy's [[Regent|regency]] in 1172, the kingdom saw turmoil which almost brought the ruling family down. The reign of William II is remembered as two decades of almost continual peace and prosperity. For this more than anything, he is nicknamed "the Good". He died in 1189 without having heirs, which led the kingdom to decline.{{Cite book|title=The Norman kingdom of Sicily |author=Donald Matthew|year=1992|pages=4–6, 71–74, 86–92, 285, 286, 304, |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|isbn=0-521-26911-3}} William II had named his aunt [[Constance of Sicily|Constance]], the daughter of Roger II who married future [[Henry VI, Holy Roman Emperor|Henry VI, Holy Roman Emperor]] his heiress. As the noblemen did not want to be ruled by a German, [[Tancred of Lecce]] seized the throne under their support, but he had to contend with the revolt of his distant cousin [[Roger of Andria]] and the invasion of Henry on behalf of his wife. Initially Roger was tricked into execution and Henry had to retreat after his attack failed, with Constance even captured and only released under the pressure of the Pope. Tancred died in 1194, and Constance and Henry eventually prevailed and the kingdom fell in 1194 to the [[House of Hohenstaufen]], with [[William III of Sicily]] the young son of Tancred deposed. Henry and Constance were crowned as king and queen. Through Constance, the [[Hauteville family|Hauteville]] blood was passed to [[Frederick I of Sicily|Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor]]. === Hohenstaufen kingdom === {{multiple image | direction = vertical | width = 230 | footer = | image1 = Liber2.jpg | alt1 = | caption1 = [[Henry VI, Holy Roman Emperor|Imperial]] troops storming [[Salerno]] in 1194 | image2 = Jindrich6 triumf.jpg | alt2 = | caption2 = Triumph march of [[Henry VI, Holy Roman Emperor|Henry VI]] into [[Palermo]] | image3 = Woodcut illustration of Constance of Sicily, her husband HRE Henry VI and her son HRE Frederick II - Penn Provenance Project.jpg | alt3 = | caption3 = Woodcut illustration of [[Constance of Sicily]], her husband [[Holy Roman Empire|Emperor]] Henry VI and her son [[Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor|Frederick II]] }} The accession of Frederick, a child who would then become also the [[Holy Roman Emperor Frederick II|Holy Roman Emperor Frederick II]] in 1197, greatly affected the immediate future of Sicily. For a land so used to centralised royal authority, the king's young age caused a serious power vacuum. His uncle [[Philip of Swabia]] moved to secure Frederick's inheritance by appointing [[Markward von Anweiler]], [[margrave]] of [[Ancona]], regent in 1198. Meanwhile, [[Pope Innocent III|Pope Innocent III]] had reasserted papal authority in Sicily, but recognised Frederick's rights. The pope was to see papal power decrease steadily over the next decade and was unsure about which side to back at many junctures. The Hohenstaufen's grip on power, however, was not secure. [[Walter III of Brienne|Walter III of Brienne]] had married the daughter of [[Tancred of Sicily]]. She was sister and heiress of the deposed King William III of Sicily. In 1201 William decided to claim the kingdom. In 1202, an army led by the chancellor [[Walter of Palearia]] and [[Dipold of Vohburg]] was defeated by Walter III of Brienne. Markward was killed, and Frederick fell under the control of [[William of Capparone]], an ally of the [[Pisa]]ns. Dipold continued the war against Walter on the mainland until the claimant's death in 1205. Dipold finally wrested Frederick from Capparone in 1206 and gave him over to the guardianship of the chancellor, Walter of Palearia. Walter and Dipold then had a falling out, and the latter captured the royal palace, where he was besieged and captured by Walter in 1207. After a decade, the wars over the regency and the throne itself had ceased. The reform of the laws began with the [[Assizes of Ariano]] in 1140 by [[Roger II of Sicily|Roger II]]. Frederick continued the reformation with the [[Assizes of Capua]] (1220) and the promulgation of the [[Constitutions of Melfi]] (1231, also known as ''[[Liber Augustalis]]''), a collection of laws for his realm that was remarkable for its time. The Constitutions of Melfi were created in order to establish a centralized state. For example, citizens were not allowed to carry weapons or wear armour in public unless they were under royal command.{{Cite book|title=Italian medieval armies 1000–1300 |author=David Nicolle |year=2002 |pages=5–10, 18–19, 34 |publisher=Osprey Publishing |isbn=1-84176-322-5}} As a result, rebellions were reduced. The Constitutions made the Kingdom of Sicily an [[absolute monarchy]], the first centralized [[Sovereign state|state]] in Europe to emerge from [[feudalism]]; it also set a precedent for the primacy of written law. With relatively small modifications, the ''Liber Augustalis'' remained the basis of Sicilian law until 1819.{{Cite book|author=James Ross Sweeney, Stanley Chodorow |title=Popes, teachers, and canon law in the Middle Ages |year=1989 |publisher=[[Cornell University Press]] |isbn=0-8014-2264-7}} During this period, he also built the [[Castel del Monte (Apulia)|Castel del Monte]], and in 1224, he founded the [[University of Naples]], now called [[Università Federico II|Università Federico II]].{{Cite book|author=Hunt Janin |title=The University in Medieval Life, 1179–1499 |year=2008 |page=132 |publisher=McFarland |isbn=0-7864-3462-7}} It remained the sole athenaeum of southern Italy for centuries. After the death of Frederick, the Kingdom was ruled by [[Henry VII of Germany|Henry VII of Germany]] and [[Conrad IV of Germany|Conrad IV of Germany]]. The next legitimate heir was [[Conradin|Conrad II]], who was too young at the period to rule. Manfred of Sicily, the illegitimate son of Frederick, took the power and ruled the kingdom for fifteen years while other Hohenstaufen heirs were ruling various areas in Germany. After long wars against the [[Papal States]], the Kingdom managed to defend its possessions, but the [[Papacy]] declared the Kingdom escheated because of disloyalty of the Hohenstaufen. Under this pretext he came to an agreement with [[Louis IX|Louis IX]], King of France. Louis's brother, [[Charles of Anjou]], would become king of Sicily. In exchange, Charles recognized the overlordship of the Pope in the Kingdom, paid a portion of the papal debt, and agreed to pay annual tribute to the Papal States.{{Cite book|author=Katherine Fisher |title=Magna Carta |year=2004|pages=53, 84–85 |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |isbn=0-313-32590-1}}{{Cite book|author = Steve Runciman |title = The Sicilian Vespers: a history of the Mediterranean world in the later thirteenth century |pages=32–34, 209, 274 |year = 1958 |publisher = [[Cambridge University Press]] |isbn = 0-521-43774-1}} The Hohenstaufen rule in Sicily ended after the 1266 [[Capetian House of Anjou|Angevin]] invasion and the death of [[Conradin]], the last male heir of Hohenstaufen, in 1268. === Angevin Sicily === [[File:Vespro22.jpg|thumb|[[Church of the Holy Spirit (Sicily)|Church of the Holy Spirit]] in Palermo.]] In 1266, conflict between the Hohenstaufen house and the Papacy led to Sicily's conquest by [[Charles I of Sicily#Conquest of Sicily|Charles I]], Duke of [[Anjou]]. With the usurpation of the Sicilian throne from Conradin by [[Manfred of Sicily]] in 1258, the relationship between the Papacy and the Hohenstaufen had changed again. Instead of the boy Conradin, safely sequestered across the Alps, the Papacy now faced an able military leader who had greatly supported the [[Guelphs and Ghibellines|Ghibelline]] cause at the battle of [[Battle of Montaperti|Montaperti]] in 1260. Accordingly, when negotiations broke down with Manfred in 1262, [[Pope Urban IV]] again took up the scheme of disseising the Hohenstaufen from the kingdom, and offered the crown to [[Charles of Anjou]] again. With Papal and [[Guelphs and Ghibellines|Guelph]] support Charles descended into Italy and defeated Manfred at the battle of [[Battle of Benevento|Benevento]] in 1266 and in 1268 Conradin at the battle of [[Battle of Tagliacozzo|Taglicozzo]]. Opposition to French officialdom and taxation combined with incitement of rebellion by agents from the [[Crown of Aragon]] and the [[Byzantine Empire]] led to the successful insurrection of the [[Sicilian Vespers]] followed by the invitation and intervention by king [[Peter III of Aragon|Peter III of Aragon]] in 1282. The resulting [[War of the Sicilian Vespers]] lasted until the [[Peace of Caltabellotta]] in 1302, dividing the old Kingdom of Sicily in two. The island of Sicily, called the "Kingdom of Sicily beyond the Lighthouse" or the Kingdom of Trinacria, went to [[Frederick III of Sicily|Frederick III]] of the [[house of Aragon]], who had been ruling it. The peninsular territories (the [[Mezzogiorno]]), contemporaneously called Kingdom of Sicily but called [[Kingdom of Naples]] by modern scholarship, went to [[Charles II of Naples|Charles II]] of the [[Capetian House of Anjou|house of Anjou]], who had likewise been ruling it. Thus, the peace was formal recognition of an uneasy ''status quo''. The division in the kingdom became permanent in 1372, with the [[Treaty of Villeneuve]]. Though the king of Spain was able to seize both crowns in the 16th century, the administrations of the two halves of the Kingdom of Sicily remained separated until 1816, when they were reunited in the [[Kingdom of Two Sicilies]]. ===The insular kingdom of Sicily under the Crown of Aragon and Spain=== [[File:Martin1Sicilsky.jpg|thumb|right|220px|[[Martin I of Sicily|Martin I]] king of Sicily in 1390-1409.]] Sicily was ruled as an independent kingdom by relatives or cadet branch of the house of Aragon until 1409 and thence as part of the [[Crown of Aragon]]. The Kingdom of Naples was ruled by the Angevin ruler [[René of Anjou]] until the two thrones were reunited by [[Alfonso V of Aragon|Alfonso V of Aragon]], after the successful siege of Naples and the defeat of René on June 6, 1443.{{Cite book|author = Allan W. Atlas |title = Music at the Aragonese court of Naples |year= 1985 |publisher = [[Cambridge University Press]] |page = 1 |isbn = 0-521-24828-0 |postscript = }} Eventually, Alfonso of Aragon divided the two kingdoms during his rule. He gave the rule of Naples to his illegitimate son [[Ferdinand I of Naples|Ferdinand I of Naples]], who ruled from 1458 to 1494, and the rest of the Crown of Aragon and Sicily to Alfonso's brother [[John II of Aragon|John II of Aragon]]. From 1494 to 1503 successive kings of France [[Charles VIII of France|Charles VIII]] and [[Louis XII|Louis XII]], who were heirs of Angevins, tried to conquer Naples (see [[Italian Wars]]) but failed. Eventually the Kingdom of Naples was reunited with the Crown of Aragon. The titles were held by the [[List of Aragonese monarchs|Aragonese kings]] of the Crown of Aragon and Kingdom of Spain until the end of the Spanish branch of the [[House of Habsburg]] in 1700. === Malta under the Knights === {{main|History of Malta under the Order of Saint John}} [[File:Prise de Malte en 1530.jpg|thumb|''[[Philippe Villiers de L'Isle-Adam|Philippe de Villiers de l'Isle Adam]] takes possession of the island of Malta, 26 October 1530'' by [[René Théodore Berthon]].]] In 1530, in an effort to protect [[Rome]] from [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] invasion from the south, [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor]], as Charles I of Spain, gave the Islands of [[Malta]] and [[Gozo]] to the [[Knights Hospitaller]] in [[History of Malta under the Order of Saint John|perpetual fiefdom]], in exchange for an [[Tribute of the Maltese Falcon|annual fee of two Maltese falcons]], which they were to send on [[All Souls' Day]] to the [[Viceroy]] of Sicily.{{Cite book|author=Carolyn Bain |title=Malta & Gozo |year=2004 |page=23 |publisher=Lonely Planet |isbn=1-74059-178-X}} The Maltese Islands had formed part of the County, and later the Kingdom of Sicily, since 1091. The feudal relationship between Malta and the Kingdom of Sicily was continued throughout the rule of the Knights, until the [[French occupation of Malta]] in 1798. The occupation was not recognized, and Malta was ''de jure'' part of the Kingdom of Sicily from 1798 to 1814. After the [[Siege of Malta (1798–1800)|Maltese rebellion]] against the French, Malta was [[Malta Protectorate|under British protection]] until it became a [[Crown Colony of Malta|British crown colony]] in 1813. This was officially recognized by the [[Treaty of Paris (1814)|Treaty of Paris]] of 1814, which marked the end of Malta's 700-year relationship with Sicily. ===The War of the Spanish Succession=== {{main|Kingdom of Sicily under Savoy}} From 1713 until 1720 the Kingdom of Sicily was ruled briefly by the [[House of Savoy]], which had received it by the terms of the [[Treaty of Utrecht]], which brought an end to the [[War of the Spanish Succession]]. The kingdom was a reward to the Savoyards, who were thus elevated to royal rank. The new king, [[Victor Amadeus II]], travelled to Sicily in 1713 and remained a year before returning to his mainland capital, [[Turin]], where his son [[Victor Amadeus, Prince of Piedmont|the Prince of Piedmont]] had been acting as regent. In Spain the results of the war had not been truly accepted, and the [[War of the Quadruple Alliance]] was the result. Sicily was occupied by Spain in 1718. When it became evident that Savoy had not the strength to defend as remote a country as Sicily, [[Archduchy of Austria|Austria]] stepped in and exchanged its [[Kingdom of Sardinia and Corsica|Kingdom of Sardinia]] for Sicily. Victor Amadeus protested this exchange, Sicily being a rich country of over one million inhabitants and Sardinia a poor country of a few hundred thousand, but he was unable to resist his "allies". Spain was finally defeated in 1720, and the [[Treaty of The Hague (1720)|Treaty of the Hague]] ratified the changeover. Sicily belonged to the Austrian Habsburgs, who already ruled Naples.{{Cite book|author=Danforth Prince |title=Frommer's Sicily |year=2007 |page=314 |publisher=Frommer's |isbn=0-470-10056-7 }} Victor Amadeus, for his part, continued to protest for three years, and only in 1723 decided to recognize the exchange and desist from using the Sicilian royal title and its subsidiary titles (such as King of Cyprus and Jerusalem). ===The two kingdoms under the house of Bourbon of Spain=== [[File:Real Casina di Caccia della Ficuzza, luglio 2010.JPG|thumb|[[Royal Palace of Ficuzza]]]] [[File:Palazzina cinese 0001.JPG|thumb|La [[Palazzina Cinese]] di Palermo, residence of Bourbon]] In 1734, Naples was reconquered by King [[Philip V of Spain]], a Bourbon, who installed his younger son, Duke Charles of Parma, as King [[Charles III of Spain|Charles VII of Naples]], starting a cadet branch of the [[house of Bourbon]]. Adding to his Neapolitan possessions, he became also King of Sicily with the name of Charles V of Sicily the next year after Austria gave up Sicily and her pretensions to Naples in exchange for the Duchy of Parma and the Grand-Duchy of Tuscany. This change of hands opened up a period of economic flourishing and social and political reformations, with many public projects and cultural initiatives directly started or inspired by the king. He remained King of Sicily until his accession to the Spanish throne in 1759, the treaties with Austria forbidding a union of the Italian domains with the crown of Spain. Charles abdicated in favour of [[Ferdinand I of the Two Sicilies|Ferdinand]], his third son, who acceded to the thrones with the names of Ferdinand IV of Naples and III of Sicily. Still a minor, Ferdinand grew up amongst pleasures and leisure while the real power was safely held by [[Bernardo Tanucci]], the president of the regency council. During this period most of the reformation process initiated by Charles came to a halt, with the king mostly absent or uninterested in the matters of state and the political helm steered by Queen Maria Carolina and prime ministers Tanucci (until 1777) and [[Jonh Francis Edward Acton|sir John Acton]]. The latter managed to disentangle Naples and Sicily from the influence of Spain and Austria and to place them nearer to Great Britain, then represented by ambassador [[William Hamilton (diplomat)|sir William Hamilton]]. This is the period of the Grand Tour, and Sicily with its many natural and historical attractions is visited by a score of intellectuals from all over Europe that on one side bring to the island the winds of the Enlightenment, and on the other side will spread the fame of its beauty in the continent. In 1799 Napoleon conquered Naples, forcing king Ferdinand and the court to flee to Sicily under the protection of the British fleet under the command of Horatio Nelson. While Naples was formed into the [[Parthenopaean Republic]] with French support and later again a kingdom under French protection and influence, Sicily became the British base of operation in the Mediterranean in the long struggle against Napoleon. Under [[British Empire|British]] guidance, especially from [[Lord William Bentinck]] who was commander of British troops in Sicily, Sicily tried to modernise its constitutional apparatus, forcing the King to ratify a Constitution moulded over the British system. The island was under British occupation from 1806-14.W. H. Clements, "The Defences of Sicily, 1806-1815," ''Journal of the Society for Army Historical Research,'' Autumn 2009, Vol. 87 Issue 351, pp 256-272 The main feature of the new system was that a two-chamber parliament was formed (instead of the three of the existing one). The formation of the parliament brought the end of [[feudalism]] in the Kingdom. After the defeat of [[Napoleon]] in 1815 Ferdinand repealed all reforms and even cancelled the Kingdom of Sicily from the map (after a history of 800 years) with the creation of the brand-new [[Kingdom of the Two Sicilies]] with capital Naples in 1816. The people of Sicily rebelled to this violation of its centuries-old statutes (which every king, including Ferdinand, had sworn to respect) but were defeated by the Neapolitan and [[House of Habsburg|Austrian]] forces in 1820. In 1848-49 another [[Sicilian revolution of independence of 1848|Sicilian revolution of independence]] occurred, which was put down by the new king [[Ferdinand II of the Two Sicilies|Ferdinand II of the Two Sicilies]], who was nicknamed ''Re Bomba'' after his 5-day bombardment of Messina. The increased hostility of the peoples and the elites of Sicily towards Naples and the Bourbon dynasty created a very unstable equilibrium, kept under control only by an increasingly oppressive police-state, political executions and exiles. ===The Tunisian-Sicilian War=== The '''Tunisian-Sicilian War''' occurred between June 1801 and April 1804, when Tunisian pirates with Tunisian and Algerian military support attacked and captured several Sicilian ships.http://daddezio.com/italy/barbary/history.html The main purpose of their attacks was to capture [[Christian]]-European [[slavery|slaves]] for the [[Muslim]]-[[Arab slave trade|Arab slave market]] in North Africa.Davis, Robert. ''Christian Slaves, Muslim Masters: White Slavery in the Mediterranean, the Barbary Coast and Italy, 1500–1800''.[https://www.amazon.com/dp/1403945519] The Sicilians defeated the forces of [[Beylik of Tunis|Tunis]] and then occupied [[Bizerte]] and [[La Goulette]] until 1808.Lambert, Frank. ''The Barbary Wars''. New York: Hill and Wang, 2005. === Unification with the Kingdom of Italy === [[File:Partenza da Quarto.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Giuseppe Garibaldi, while leaving from Quarto with his soldiers|The beginning of the Expedition of the Thousand at Quarto.]] On April 4, 1860 the latest revolt against the [[House of Bourbon|Bourbon]] regime broke out. [[Giuseppe Garibaldi]], funded and directed by the Piedmontese prime minister Cavour, assisted the revolt with his forces, launching the so-called [[Expedition of the Thousand]]. He arrived at [[Marsala]] on May 11, 1860 with ca. 1,000 [[Redshirts (Italy)|Redshirts]]. Garibaldi announced that he was assuming [[dictatorship of Garibaldi|dictatorship over Sicily]] in the name of King [[Victor Emmanuel II of Italy|Victor Emmanuel II]] of Sardinia. On May 15, the Redshirts fought the [[Battle of Calatafimi]] and within weeks Palermo was freed from the troops of general Lanza, who even being superior in number, inexplicably retreated. [[Francis II of the Two Sicilies|Francis II of the Two Sicilies]] tried to regain control of the Kingdom. On June 25, 1860 he restored the constitution of the Kingdom, adopted the Italian [[Flag of Italy|tricolour]] as the national flag, and promised special institutions for the Kingdom.{{Cite book|author=Alfonso Scirocco |title=Garibaldi: citizen of the world |year=2007 |page=279 |publisher=[[Princeton University Press]] |isbn=0-691-11540-0 }} On October 21, 1860 a plebiscite regarding the unification with Italy was conducted. The outcome of the referendum was 432,053 (99%) in favour and only 667 in opposition to the unification. With three separate armies still fighting within the Kingdom, this outcome was far from an accurate depiction of public opinion. Substantial inconsistencies as well as the absence of secret ballot further complicate the interpretation of the referendum, which Dennis Mack Smith describes as being "obviously rigged".{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=axgfeXGFvF8C&lpg=PA17&dq=plebiscite%25201860%2520sicily%2520mack%2520smith&pg=PA17#v=onepage&q=obviously%2520rigged&f=false|title=Italy and Its Garibaldi 1860: A Study in Political Conflict|last=Smith|first=Denis Mack|date=1985-04-18|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=|isbn=9780521316378|location=|pages=389|language=en|via=}}{{Cite & Mafiosi: Origin, Power and Myth|last=Hess|first=Henner|date=1998-01-01|publisher=NYU Press|year=|isbn=9781863331432|location=|pages=155|language=en|via=}}{{Cite Consciousness: The Remembered Past|last=Lukacs|first=John|date=1968-01-01|publisher=Transaction Publishers|year=|isbn=9781412825146|location=|pages=116|language=en|via=}}{{Cite
