the State: The Formation of Italy and Germany and the Puzzle of Federalism|last=Ziblatt|first=Daniel|date=2006-01-01|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|year=|isbn=0691121672|location=|pages=102|language=en|via=}}{{Cite book|title=Western civilization|last=Noble|first=Thomas F. X.|publisher=Houghton Mifflin|year=1994|isbn=|location=|pages=895|via=}} Most Sicilians viewed the unification as acceptance of the House of Savoy, in which belonged [[Victor Emmanuel II of Italy|Victor Emmanuel II]], the first king of Italy. == Society == During the Norman Kingdom of Sicily, the local communities maintained their privileges. The rulers of the Hohenstaufen Kingdom replaced the local nobility with lords from northern Italy, leading to clashes and rebellions against the new nobility in many cities and rural communities. These revolts resulted in the destruction of many agrarian areas and the rise of middle class nationalism, which eventually led to urban dwellers becoming allies of the [[Crown of Aragon|Aragonese]]. This situation was continued during the short rule of the Angevin until their overthrowing during the Sicilian Vespers. The Angevin began feudalising the country, increasing the power of the nobility by granting them jurisdiction over high justice.{{Cite book|author=Samantha Kelly |title=The new Solomon: Robert of Naples (1309–1343) and fourteenth-century kingship |year=2003 |page=134 |publisher=BRILL |isbn=90-04-12945-6}} During the 15th century due to the isolation of the Kingdom, the Renaissance had no impact on it.{{Citation needed|date=July 2017}} At the same period the feudalisation of the Kingdom of Sicily was intensified, through the enforcement of feudal bonds and relations among its subjects. In 1669 the eruption of [[Mount Etna]] destroyed [[Catania]]. In 1693, 5% of the Kingdom's population was killed because of [[1693 Sicily earthquake|earthquakes]]. In that period there were also plague outbreaks. The 17th and 18th century were an era of decline of the Kingdom. Corruption was prevalent among the upper and middle classes of the society. Widespread corruption and maltreatment of the lower classes by the feudal lords led to the creation of groups of brigands, attacking the nobility and destroying their [[fief]]s. These groups which were self-named "Mafia", were the foundation of the modern [[Sicilian Mafia]]. The escalation of revolts against the monarchy eventually led to the unification with Italy.{{Cite book|author=Lucy Riall |title=Sicily and the unification of Italy: liberal policy and local power, 1859–1866 |year=1998 |page=206 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |isbn= 0-19-820680-1}} == Demographics == During the reign of [[Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor|Frederick II]] the kingdom had a population of about 2.5 million.{{Cite book|author=Kenneth M. Setton |title=A History of the Crusades, Volume V: The Impact of the Crusades on the Near East |year=1985 |page=313 |publisher=[[University of Wisconsin Press]] |isbn=0-299-09144-9 }} During the Hohenstaufen era, the Kingdom had 3 towns with a population of over 20,000 each.{{Cite book|author=Perry Anderson |title=Lineages of the Absolutist State |year=1984 |page=146 |publisher=Verso |isbn=0-86091-710-X }} After the loss of the northern provinces in 1282 during the [[Sicilian Vespers]] and several natural disasters like the eruption of Mount Etna in 1669, the population of the Kingdom of Sicily was reduced. In 1803 the population of the Kingdom was 1,656,000.{{Cite book|author=Jedidiah Morse |title=A compendious and complete system of modern geography: or, A view of the present state of the world. |page=503 |publisher=Thomas and Andrews }} The main cities of the Kingdom at that period were [[Palermo]], [[Catania]], [[Messina]], [[Modica]], [[Syracuse, Sicily|Syracuse]]. {| class="wikitable" border="1" |+ Population of the Kingdom of Sicily in 1803 ! Division !! Population |- | Val di Mazzara || 643,000 |- | Val di Demona || 521,000 |- | [[Val di Noto]] || 459,000 |- | [[Lipari Islands]] || 18,000 |- | [[Aegadian Islands]] || 12,000 |- | [[Pantelleria|Pantelleria Island]] || 3,000 |- ! Total Population | 1,656,000 |} {| class="wikitable" border="1" |+ Population of the main cities of the Kingdom of Sicily in 1803 ! City !! Population |- | [[Palermo]] || 120,000 |- | [[Catania]] || 40,000 |- | [[Messina]] || 36,000 |- | [[Modica]] || 23,500 |- | [[Syracuse, Sicily|Syracuse]] || 17,000 |} == Economy == {{See also|Subventio generalis}} [[File:Ravello BW 2013-05-15 12-31-34 DxO.jpg|thumb|right|alt=View of the coast of Amalfi from the mountainside|Amalfi, an important port during the Norman Kingdom.]] The high fertility of the land led the Norman kings to bring settlers from neighbouring regions or to resettle farmers to areas where cultivation of land was needed. This led to increase of agrarian production. The main sources of wealth for the Kingdom of Sicily at that period were its maritime cities, most important of which were [[Naples]] and [[Amalfi]], from which local products were exported. The main export was hard [[grain]], with other products exported including [[nut (fruit)|nut]]s, [[timber]], [[oil]], bacon, [[cheese]], skins, [[hide (skin)|hide]]s, [[hemp]] and [[cloth]]. Grain and other dry products were measured in salme, which was equivalent to 275.08 litres in the western part of the Kingdom, and 3.3 litres in the eastern part. The salma was divided in 16 tumoli. One tumolo was equivalent to 17,193 [[litre]]s. Weight was measured in cantari. One cantaro was equivalent to {{convert|79.35|kg}} and was divided in one hundred rottoli. Cloth was measured in canne. One canna was 2.06 meters long. By the end of the 12th century [[Messina]] had become one of the leading commercial cities of the kingdom. Under the Kingdom, Sicily's products went to many different lands. Among these were [[Republic of Genoa|Genoa]], [[Republic of Pisa|Pisa]], the [[Byzantine Empire]], and [[Arab Republic of Egypt|Egypt]]. Over the course of the 12th century, Sicily became an important source of raw materials for north Italian cities such as Genoa. As the centuries went on, however, this economic relationship became less advantageous to Sicily, and some modern scholars see the relationship as frankly exploitative.Henri Bresc (in ''Un monde mediteranéen'') claims that Sicily was reduced to an agricultural hinterland for wealthier northern Italian cities, and sees the Sicilian people as an early proletariat Furthermore, many scholars believe that Sicily went into decline in the late Middle Ages, though they are not agreed on when this decline occurred. Clifford Backman argues that it is a mistake to see the economic history of Sicily in terms of victimization, and contends that the decline really began in the second part of the reign of Frederick III, in contrast to earlier scholars who believed that Sicilian decline had set in earlier.Backman, ''The Decline and Fall of Medieval Sicily,'' 1995. Where earlier scholars saw late medieval Sicily in continuous decline, Stephen Epstein argued that Sicilian society experienced something of a revival in the 15th century.Epstein, ''An Island for Itself: Economic Development and Social Change in Late Medieval Sicily,'' (2003). Various treaties with Genoa secured and strengthened the commercial power of Sicily. The feudalising of the society during the Angevin rule reduced royal wealth and treasury. The dependence of the Angevin on north Italian commerce and financing by [[Florence|Florentine]] bankers were the main factors which led to the decline of the Kingdom's economy. The continuation of the economic decline combined with the increased population and [[urbanization]] led to decrease of agrarian production. In 1800 one-third of the available crops was cultivated with obsolete cultivation methods escalating the problem. In the later period of Spanish rule the trading system was also inefficient in comparison with previous periods because of high taxes on exports and monopolising corporations which had total control of prices.{{Cite book|author=Desmond Gregory |title=Sicily: the insecure base: a history of the British occupation of Sicily, 1806–1815 |year=1988 |page=35 |publisher=Fairleigh Dickinson Univ Press |isbn=0-8386-3306-4}} == Coinage == [[File:Augustale.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A gold coin, which depicts the bust of a man and an eagle|Example of a Messinese augustale.]] The Norman kings in the 12th century used the [[tarì|tari]], which had been used in Sicily from 913 as the basic coin. One tari weighed about one gram and was {{frac|16|1|3}} carats of gold. The [[Arab]] [[dinar]] was worth four tari, and the [[Byzantine]] [[Solidus (coin)|solidus]] six tari. In the kingdom one onza was equivalent to thirty tari or five florins. One tari was worth twenty grani. One grana was equivalent to six denari. After 1140 the circulation of the copper coin romesina stopped and it was replaced by the follaris. Twenty four follari were equivalent to one Byzantine [[miliaresion]]. After defeating the [[History of medieval Tunisia|Tunisians]] in 1231 [[Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor]] minted the [[augustalis]]. It was minted in {{frac|21|1|2}} carats and weighed 5.28 grams.{{Cite book|author=Peter L. Bernstein |title=The power of gold: the history of an obsession |year=2000 |page=90 |publisher=John Wiley and Sons |isbn=0-471-25210-7}} In 1490 the triumphi were minted in Sicily. They were equivalent to the [[Republic of Venice|Venetian]] [[ducat]]. One triumpho was worth {{frac|11|1|2}} aquilae. One aquila was worth twenty grani. In transactions tari and pichuli were mainly used. [[File:Arms of the Aragonese Kings of Sicily with Crest.svg|thumb|Coat of arms of the [[Crown of Aragon|Aragonsese]] monarchs of Sicily.]] == Religion == During the Norman reign, several different religious communities coexisted in the Kingdom of Sicily. They were: Latin Christians ([[Roman Catholicism|Roman Catholics]]), Greek-speaking Christians ([[Eastern Orthodoxy|Eastern Orthodox]]), [[Islam|Muslims]] and [[Judaism|Jews]]. Although local religious practices were not interrupted, the fact that Latin Christians were in power tended to favor Latin Christianity (Roman Catholicism). Bishops of the Eastern Orthodox rite were obliged to recognize the claims of the Latin Church in Sicily, while Muslim communities were no longer ruled by local [[emir]]s. Greek-speaking Christians, Latin Christians, and Muslims interacted on a regular basis, and were involved in each other's lives, economically, linguistically, and culturally. Some intermarried. Christians living in an Arabic-speaking area might adopt Arabic or even Muslim names.Metcalfe, Alex. ''Muslims and Christians in Norman Sicily. Arabic Speakers and the End of Islam'', (2003). In many cities, each religious community had its own administrative and judicial order. In [[Palermo]], Muslims were allowed to publicly call for prayer in mosques, and their legal issues were settled by [[qadi]]s, judges who ruled in accordance with Islamic law. After the establishment of Hohenstaufen authority Latin- and Greek-speaking Christians maintained their privileges, but the Muslim population was increasingly oppressed. The settlements of Italians brought from northern Italy (who wanted Muslim property for their own) led many Muslim communities to revolt or resettle in mountainous areas of Sicily. These revolts resulted in some acts of violence, and the eventual deportation of Muslims, which began under [[Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor|Frederick II]]. Eventually, the government removed the entire Muslim population to [[Lucera]] in [[Apulia]] and [[Girifalco]] in [[Calabria]], where they paid taxes and served as agricultural laborers, craftsmen, and crossbowmen for the benefit of the king. The colony at Lucera was finally disbanded in 1300 under [[Charles II of Naples]], and many of its inhabitants sold into slavery.The best discussion of the fate of Sicilian Muslims can be found in Julie Taylor, ''Muslims in Medieval Italy: The Colony at Lucera'' (2003), but is also discussed in Alex Metcalfe, ''The Muslims of Medieval Italy'' (2009). The Jewish community was [[Expulsion of the Jews from Sicily|expelled]] after the establishment of the Spanish Inquisition from 1493 to 1513 in Sicily. The remaining Jews were gradually assimilated, and most of them converted to Roman Catholicism. == See also == {{Div col}} *[[Angelo da Furci]] *[[Arab-Norman culture]] *[[County palatine of Cephalonia and Zakynthos]] *[[Emirate of Sicily]] *[[Expedition of the Thousand]] *[[Expulsion of the Jews from Sicily]] *[[Kingdom of Naples]] *[[Kingdom of the Two Sicilies]] *[[List of Sicilian monarchs]] *[[Norman conquest of southern Italy]] *[[Redshirts (Italy)|Redshirts]] *[[Sicilian Parliament]] *[[Tunisian-Sicilian War]] *[[War of the Sicilian Vespers]] {{div col end}} == References == {{Reflist}} == Sources == *Abulafia, David. ''Frederick II: A Medieval Emperor,'' 1988. *Abulafia, David. ''The Two Italies: Economic Relations between the Kingdom of Sicily and the Northern Communes,'' Cambridge University Press, 1977. *Abulafia, David. ''The Western Mediterranean Kingdoms 1200–1500: The Struggle for Dominion,'' Longman, 1997. (a political history) *Johns, Jeremy. ''Arabic administration in Norman Sicily : the royal dīwān,'' Cambridge University Press, 2002. *Mendola, Louis; Alio, Jacqueline. ''The Peoples of Sicily: A Multicultural Legacy,'' Trinacria Editions, New York, 2013. *Mendola, Louis. ''The Kingdom of Sicily 1130-1860,'' Trinacria Editions, New York, 2015. *Metcalfe, Alex. ''Muslims and Christians in Norman Sicily: Arabic Speakers and the End of Islam,'' Routledge, 2002. *Metcalfe, Alex. ''The Muslims of Medieval Italy,'' 2009. *Norwich, John Julius. ''Sicily: An Island at the Crossroads of History,'' 2015. *Runciman, Steven. ''The Sicilian Vespers: A History of the Mediterranean World in the Late 13th Century,'' Cambridge University Press, 1958. {{Former monarchies Italian peninsula}} {{Spanish Empire}} {{The Bourbons of Naples and Sicily (1735–1816)}} {{Royal palaces in the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies}} {{Sicily}} {{Malta topics}} {{Good article}} {{coord missing|Italy}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sicily, Kingdom Of}} [[Category:Kingdom of Sicily| ]] [[Category:History of Sicily|Kingdom of Sicily]] [[Category:Medieval Sicily|*Kingdom of Sicily]] [[Category:Medieval Italy|Kingdom of Sicily]] [[Category:High Middle Ages|Kingdom of Sicily]] [[Category:Italian Renaissance|Kingdom of Sicily]] [[Category:Crown of Aragon]] [[Category:Napoleonic Wars|Kingdom of Sicily]] [[Category:States and territories established in 1130|Kingdom of Sicily]] [[Category:States and territories disestablished in 1861|Kingdom of Sicily]] [[Category:1130 establishments in Europe]] [[Category:12th-century establishments in Italy]] [[Category:1861 disestablishments in Italy|Kingdom of Sicily]] [[Category:Former countries on the Italian Peninsula|Kingdom of Sicily]] [[Category:Former monarchies of Europe]] [[Category:Island countries|Kingdom of Sicily]]

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=November 2010}} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Malta}} "Little Child" | image = | caption = | year = 1992 | country = Malta | artist = [[Mary Spiteri]] | as = | with = | language = English | composer = Georgina Abela | lyricist = Raymond Mahoney | conductor = Paul Abela | place = 3rd | points = 123 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1992mt from Diggiloo Thrush] | clip = [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p0iz0GUWlSg from YouTube] | prev = Could It Be | prev_link = Could It Be (Georgina & Paul Giordimaina song) | next = This Time | next_link = This Time (William Mangion song) }} {{for|the song by the Beatles|Little Child}} '''"Little Child"''' was the [[Malta|Maltese]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1992]], performed in [[English language|English]] by [[Mary Spiteri]].
The song is a ballad, in which Spiteri addresses the titular "little child" and informs him or her that she has become old and cynical - as well as delivering the warning that this is the result of growing older. All is not lost, however, as the innocence of the child inspires Spiteri to see the world in a more positive manner.
The song was performed tenth on the night (following [[Cyprus]]' [[Evridiki]] with "[[Teriazume]]" and preceding [[Iceland]]'s [[Heart 2 Heart (band)|Heart 2 Heart]] with "[[Nei Eða Já]]"). At the close of voting, it had received 123 points, placing 3rd in a field of 23—and thus bettering Malta's previous best result set in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1991|1991]] by a duo featuring [[Georgina Abela]], who composed this entry.
A [[Maltese language]] version was also recorded, titled '''"Tfajjel Ċkejken"'''.
It was succeeded as [[Malta in the Eurovision Song Contest|Maltese representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1993|1993 Contest]] by [[William Mangion]] with "[[This Time (Eurovision song)|This Time]]".
{{Malta in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1992}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Little Child (Song)}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of Malta]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1992]] [[Category:1992 songs]]
{{malta-stub}}

{{Infobox language |name=Luvale |states=[[Angola]], [[Zambia]] |region= |ethnicity=[[Lovale]] |speakers={{sigfig|635,000|2}} |date=2001–2010 |ref=e18 |familycolor=Niger-Congo |fam2=[[Atlantic–Congo languages|Atlantic–Congo]] |fam3=[[Benue–Congo languages|Benue–Congo]] |fam4=[[Bantoid languages|Bantoid]] |fam5=[[Bantu languages|Bantu]] ([[Guthrie classification of Bantu languages#Zone K|Zone K]]) |fam6=[[Chokwe–Luchazi languages|Chokwe–Luchazi]] (K.10) |minority=[[Zambia]] |script=[[Latin script|Latin]] (Luvale alphabet)
[[Luvale Braille]] |iso3=lue |glotto=luva1239 |glottorefname=Luvale |guthrie=K.14 }} '''Luvale''' (also spelt Chiluvale, Lovale, Lubale, Luena, Lwena) is a [[Bantu languages|Bantu language]] spoken by the [[Lovale people]] of [[Angola]] and [[Zambia]]. It is recognised as a regional language for educational and administrative purposes in Zambia, where about 168,000 (2006) people speak it. Luvale is closely related to [[Chokwe language|Chokwe]]. ==In fiction== In the Swedish 1997 [[murder mystery]] novel "[[Faceless Killers]]", Inspector [[Kurt Wallander]] investigates a murderous racist attack on a refugee center in [[Skane]] and finds it difficult to communicate with a witness who speaks only the Luvale language. The problem is resolved when a 90-year-old woman is found, who is a former missionary who speaks Luvale fluently, and she acts as the interpreter. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Cite web | title = Luvale Reading Lessons | work = Lubuto Library Special Collections | accessdate = 2014-05-04 | url = http://lubutocollections.org/items/show/81 }} *Moses C.B. Mulongesa, ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20150621021714/http://lubutocollections.org/items/show/74 Vishimo vya Kuuko],'' Lubuto Library Special Collections, accessed May 3, 2014. *[http://lubutocollections.org/items/browse?search=luvale&submit_search=Search Luvale language books]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Lubuto Library Special Collections *[http://www.language-archives.org/language/lue OLAC resources in and about the Luvale language] {{Languages of Angola}} {{Languages of Zambia}} {{Narrow Bantu languages|J-M}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Chokwe-Luchazi languages]] [[Category:Languages of Angola]] [[Category:Languages of Zambia]] [[Category:Library of Congress Africa Collection related]] {{Angola-stub}} {{Zambia-stub}} {{Bantu-lang-stub}}

{{unreferenced|date=July 2014}} [[File:Sahel Map-Africa rough.png|thumb|right|300px|The Sahel forms a belt up to 1,000 km wide, spanning Africa from the [[Atlantic Ocean]] to the [[Red Sea]].]] The '''Sahelian kingdoms''' were a series of kingdoms or [[African empires|empires]] that were centered on the [[Sahel]], the area of grasslands south of the [[Sahara]]. The wealth of the states came from controlling the trade routes across the desert. Their power came from having large [[pack animal]]s like [[camel]]s and [[horse]]s that were fast enough to keep a large empire under central control and were also useful in such kind of battle. All of these empires were also quite decentralized with member cities having a great deal of autonomy.
The Sahel states were limited from expanding south into the [[forest zone]] of the [[Ashanti people|Ashanti]] and [[Yoruba people|Yoruba]] as mounted warriors were all but useless in the forests and the horses and camels could not survive the heat and diseases of the region.
==Economy== There were integrated kingdoms and empires, with substantial cities and significant towns; and less organised territories with large scattered populations. People practised agriculture, stock-rearing, hunting, fishing, and crafts (metalworking, textiles, ceramics). They navigated along rivers and across lakes, trading over short and long distances, using their own currencies.
==History of Sahel kingdoms== *The first major state to rise in this region was the [[Kingdom of Ghana]]. Established in c. the 8th century, it was centered in what is today [[Senegal]] and [[Mauritania]], it was the first to benefit from the introduction of pack animals by [[Wolof people|Wolof]] traders. Ghana dominated the region between about 750 and 1078. Smaller states in the region at this time included [[Takrur]] to the west, the [[Malinke]] kingdom of Mali to the south, and the Songhai centred on [[Gao]] to the east. *When Ghana collapsed in the face of invasion from the [[Almoravids]], a series of brief kingdoms followed, notably that of the [[Sosso]]; after 1235, the [[Mali Empire]] rose to dominate the region. Located on the [[Niger River]] to the west of Ghana in what is today [[Niger]] and [[Mali]], it reached its peak in the 1350s, but had lost control of a number of vassal states by 1400. *The most powerful of these states was the [[Songhai Empire]], which expanded rapidly beginning with king [[Sonni Ali]] in the 1460s. By 1500, it had risen to stretch from [[Cameroon]] to the [[Maghreb]], the largest state in African history. It too was quite short-lived and collapsed in 1591 as a result of [[Morocco|Moroccan]] [[musket]]ry. *Far to the east, on [[Lake Chad]], the state of [[Bornu Empire|Kanem-Bornu]], founded as Kanem in the 9th century, now rose to greater preeminence in the central Sahel region. To their west, the loosely united [[Hausa Kingdoms|Hausa city-states]] became dominant. These two states coexisted uneasily, but were quite stable. *In 1810 the [[Fulani Empire]] rose and conquered the Hausa, creating a more centralized state. It and Kanem-Bornu would continue to exist.
==Maps== <gallery widths=200px heights=200px>

File:EthniesSénégal.jpg|Carte des peuplades du Sénégal de l'abbé Boilat (1853): an ethnic map of Senegal at the time of French colonialism. The pre-colonial states of Baol, Sine and Saloum are arrayed along the southwest coast, with the inland areas marked "Peuple Sérère".
File:SONGHAI empire map.PNG|The [[Songhai Empire]] c. 1500
File:Bornu15century.jpg|[[Bornu Empire]] territory by 1500

File:TombouctouPachalik 4.png|Map of the [[Pashalik of Timbuktu]] (yellow-striped) as part of the [[Saadi dynasty|Saadi dynasty of Morocco]] (outlined black) within the [[Songhai Empire]] (outlined red), c. 1591

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Siti Aisyah}} {{Infobox scientist | image = Siti Aisyah Alias.jpeg | image_size = | caption = Siti Aisyah Alias | birth_name = Siti Aisah Binti Hj Alias | birth_date = {{birth date and age |1966|03|25}} | nationality = Malaysian | fields = Polar [[mycology]] | workplaces = National Antarctic Research Centre, [[University of Malaya]] | alma_mater = [[University of Malaya]] }}
'''Siti Aisah Binti Hj Alias''' is a Malaysian marine polar researcher and lecturer. As of August 2016, she is Associate Professor and Deputy Director of the National Antarctic Research Centre (NARC) in the Malaysian Antarctic Research Programme (MARP), at the [[University of Malaya]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Organisational Structure of the Malaysian Antarctic Research Programme |url=http://cmsad.um.edu.my/index1.php?pfct=narc&modul=About_Us&pilihan=Organisation_Structure |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160916053537/http://cmsad.um.edu.my/index1.php?pfct=narc&modul=About_Us&pilihan=Organisation_Structure |archivedate=2016-09-16 |df= }}</ref> Her work focuses on the physiology of marine and polar microbes and fungi.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://ww1.utusan.com.my/utusan/info.asp?y=2004&dt=0207&pub=utusan_malaysia&sec=Rencana&pg=re_06.htm&arc=hive|title=Mempelbagaikan fungsi kulat|website=Utusan Online|access-date=2016-07-19}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Alias was born on March 25, 1966 in Malaysia. She studied at Tunku Ampuan Durah from 1981 to 1983. She graduated from the [[University of Malaya]], Malaysia with a BSc in Ecology in 1991. She earned a PhD in marine [[mycology]] at the [[University of Portsmouth]] in 1996. She returned to Malaysia to work as a lecturer at the Institute of Biological Sciences, UM, and started a research program on marine mycology, later pursuing polar research on fungal diversity and enzymology. In 2015, she was transferred to Institute of Ocean and Earth Sciences (IOES).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ioes.um.edu.my|title=IOES - Home Page|website=www.ioes.um.edu.my|access-date=2016-07-27|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160916061820/http://www.ioes.um.edu.my/|archivedate=2016-09-16|df=}}</ref>
==Career and impact== Since 2001, Alias has been the Deputy Director of the National Antarctic Research Centre (NARC) and Malaysian Antarctic Research Programme (MARP).<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://umexpert.um.edu.my/saa.html|title=UMEXPERT - ASSOCIATE PROF. DR. SITI AISAH BINTI HJ ALIAS|website=umexpert.um.edu.my|access-date=2016-07-19}}</ref> She is a National Delegate member for the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR) representing Malaysia,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scar.org/scar_media/documents/news/2016/AFoPS_12-2015.pdf|title=SCAR Media|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160924001828/http://www.scar.org/scar_media/documents/news/2016/AFoPS_12-2015.pdf#|archive-date=2016-09-24|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Committee Member for the Asian Forum on Polar Science (AFOPS)<ref>{{cite web|title=Asian Forum on Polar Science|url=http://www.afops.org/m12.php|access-date=2016-07-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160828130345/http://www.afops.org/m12.php#|archive-date=2016-08-28|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> and a Task Force Member, Academy of Science Malaysia for the Malaysian Antarctic Program.
As a principle investigator for MARP,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://asmic.akademisains.gov.my/download/estidotmy/2003/edisi_19_2003.pdf|title=Estidotmy|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> her scientific research fields include fungal biodiversity<ref name=":0" /> and phylobiogeography, antimicrobial activity and cold-adapted enzymes and biochemistry of Antarctic microbes.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GFAnPZsdhPsC|title=The Emerging Politics of Antarctica|last=Brady|first=Anne-Marie|date=2012-11-27|publisher=[[Routledge]]|isbn=9781135136949|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1309&dat=20031202&id=g0AhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=v3sFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2444,2429128&hl=en|title=New Straits Times - Google News Archive Search|website=news.google.com|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> Her strong commitment to the development of the Malaysian national Antarctic research community, and Malaysia's standing within both SCAR and the [[Antarctic Treaty System]], is illustrated by her establishment of important international collaborations with several national Antarctic Institutes and research communities, including those of Ecuador,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.inae.gob.ec/wp-content/uploads/Ecuador-Ant%C3%A1rtico-revista-4.pdf|title=Ecuador Antartico revisita|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160915162717/http://www.inae.gob.ec/wp-content/uploads/Ecuador-Ant%C3%A1rtico-revista-4.pdf|archivedate=2016-09-15|df=}}</ref> Australia, Chile, Poland and the United Kingdom.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.antarctica.gov.au/magazine/2001-2005/issue-4-spring-2002/international2/malaysian-scientists-head-south-with-australia|title=Malaysian scientists head south with Australia|website=www.antarctica.gov.au|language=en-au|access-date=2016-07-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cmsad.um.edu.my/index1.php?pfct=narc&modul=Research_Activites&pilihan=Biological_Sciences&subpilihan=Assoc._Prof._Dr._Siti_Aishah_Alias|title=National Antarctic Research Centre|website=cmsad.um.edu.my|access-date=2016-07-19|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160916052954/http://cmsad.um.edu.my/index1.php?pfct=narc&modul=Research_Activites&pilihan=Biological_Sciences&subpilihan=Assoc._Prof._Dr._Siti_Aishah_Alias|archivedate=2016-09-16|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ypasm.my/download/rothera-report2015_Yoga.pdf|title=Rothera Report 2015|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> She also has significant field experience in the Antarctic and Arctic, participating in several polar research expeditions (2000-2010).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2006/10/02/trio-tell-of-arctic-experience/|title=Trio tell of Arctic experience - Nation {{!}} The Star Online|last=Chapman|first=Karen|access-date=2016-07-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.researchinsvalbard.no/project/7111|title=Research in Svalbard (RiS) Portal|website=www.researchinsvalbard.no|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref>
She is assisting the development of Malaysia's Antarctic policies and practices following the country's recent accession to the Antarctic Treaty, under a grant from [[Ministry of Higher Education (Malaysia)|Ministry of Higher Education]] for the development of Science and Policy in Antarctica (2011-2016). She will lead a Higher Institute of Centre of Excellence project on "Latitudinal Differences in Response and Adaptation of Microbes to Atmospheric Changes", at the Institute of Ocean and Earth Sciences (IOES), University of Malaya.<ref name=":1" />
==Awards and honours== Siti Aisyah Alias was awarded the National Young Scientist Award, Ministry of Science, Technology and Environmental, Malaysia (2001), a Science and Technology Research Grant from the Toray Science Foundation (2005), and a Fellowship from the [[United Nations University]], Tokyo, Japan, UNESCO, Paris (2008).<ref name=":1"/>
